summary: The U.S. District Court for the Western District of Texas today entered a final judgment against a Texas mother and her two children in a wrongful termination case.  The SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in Dallas, alleges that P.S.-R. Melissa R. R. (Mother) signed an affidavit of relinquishment of her parental rights to her children in April 2017. The complaint alleges that R.R. signed the affidavit because she believed it would allow her mother to obtain custody of and adopt her children, and that she understood the effect of the relinquishment. The SEC also alleges that, as alleged in the complaint, R.S., R.  R.L.’s, R&n;s and R&r;s.   Â that the affidavit was voluntary and that the court could pick her up and terminate the parental rights if she did not sign the affidavit.  In a parallel action, the United States Attorney’s Office for the Southern District of New York today announced criminal charges against R. S. (R. &n;R.&rd;s) mother, who was charged with violating Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder, and Section 15(a) of Exchange Act Rule 15b2-1 thereunder. The court granted the SECs request for a temporary restraining order, an asset freeze, and an officer-and-director bar. The case is being supervised by Chedly C. Dumornay. The litigation will be led by Jennifer C. Barry and supervised by Amy C. Welshhans.Â  The SEC appreciates the assistance of the Texas Department of Family and Protective Services, the Federal Bureau of Investigation, and the Texas Office of Child Advocacy and Advocacy.
